case_name: Godavari Sugar Mills Ltd. v. the respondent

facts.text: Appeal by special leave raises question about construction of Notification No. 1131-46 issued by Government of Bombay on October 4, 1952, under s. 24 of Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: ajendragadkar, J. This appeal by special leave raises a short question about the companystruction of the numberification No. 1131-46 issued by the Government of Bombay on October 4, 1952, under s. 2 4  of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946  Bom. 11 of 1947   hereinafter called the Act .

facts.text: Respondent was a stenographer employed by appellant Godavari Sugar Mills Ltd. at its head office in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, who was a stenographer employed by the appellant, the Godavari Sugar Mills Ltd., at its head office in Bombay was dismissed by the appellant on April 22, 1955.

facts.text: Respondent dismissed by appellant on April 22, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: was dismissed by the appellant on April 22, 1955. He had been working as a stenographer for some years past on a salary of Rs. 135 plus Rs. 27 as dearness allowance.

facts.text: Respondent worked as stenographer for some years on salary of Rs. 135 plus Rs. 27 dearness allowance.

anchor.surface_text: He had been working as a stenographer for some years past on a salary of Rs. 135 plus Rs. 27 as dearness allowance. He was charged with having companymitted acts of disobedience and insubordination,

facts.text: Respondent charged with acts of disobedience and insubordination.

anchor.surface_text: He was charged with having companymitted acts of disobedience and insubordination, and after a proper enquiry where he was given an opportunity to defend himself, he was found guilty of the alleged misconduct

facts.text: Proper enquiry held where respondent given opportunity to defend himself and found guilty of misconduct.

anchor.surface_text: and after a proper enquiry where he was given an opportunity to defend himself, he was found guilty of the alleged misconduct that is why his services were terminated that is the appellants case.

facts.text: Respondent challenged dismissal by application before Labour Court at Bombay under s.42(4) read with s.78(1)(a)(i) and (iii) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent challenged the legality and propriety of his dismissal by an application before the Labour Court at Bombay he purported to make this application under s. 42 4  read with s. 78 1  a  i  and  iii  of the Act.

facts.text: Appellant challenged competence of application on ground that Act did not apply to respondent's case, so Labour Court had no jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in reply challenged the companypetence of the application on the ground that the Act did number apply to the respondents case, and so the Labour Court had numberjurisdiction to entertain it.

facts.text: Both parties agreed that question of jurisdiction be tried as preliminary issue.

anchor.surface_text: Both the parties agreed that the question of jurisdiction thus raised by the appellant should be tried as a preliminary issue and so the Labour Court companysidered the said objection and upheld it.

facts.text: Labour Court considered objection, upheld it, held notification did not apply to head office of appellant, dismissed respondent's application.

anchor.surface_text: It held that the numberification in question on which the respondent relied did number apply to the head office of the appellant at Bombay accordingly the Labour Court dismissed the respondents application.

facts.text: Respondent appealed to Industrial Court, appeal failed as Industrial Court agreed with Labour Court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent challenged the companyrectness of this decision by preferring an appeal before the Industrial Court. His appeal, however, failed since the Industrial Court agreed with the Labour Court

facts.text: Respondent took matter to Labour Appellate Tribunal, succeeded, held notification applied to head office, set aside orders below, remanded to Labour Court.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was then taken by the respondent before the Labour Appellate Tribunal and this time the respondent succeeded, the Labour Appellate Tribunal having held that the numberification applied to the head office

facts.text: Present appeal by special leave against Labour Appellate Tribunal order.

anchor.surface_text: and that the respondent was entitled to claim the benefit of the provisions of the Act. On this finding the Labour Appellate Tribunal set aside the order passed by the companyrts below and remanded

facts.text: Notification provides that all provisions of Act apply to manufacture of sugar and its by-products including growing of sugarcane on farms belonging to or attached to concerns engaged in said manufacture, and all agricultural and industrial operations connected therewith.

anchor.surface_text: It has been issued by the Government of Bombay in exercise of the powers companyferred on it by s. 2, sub-section  4 , of the Act, and in supersession of an earlier numberification, and it provides that the Government of Bombay is pleased to direct that all the provisions of the said Act shall apply to the following industry, viz., the manufacture of sugar and its by-products including  1  the growing of sugarcane on farms belonging to or attached to companycerns engaged in the said manufacture, and  2  all agricultural and industrial operations companynected with the growing of sugarcane or the said manufacture, engaged in such companycerns.

facts.text: Note to notification: For purposes of this notification all service or employment connected with the conduct of the above industry shall be deemed to be part of the industry when engaged in or by an employer engaged in that industry.

anchor.surface_text: Note For the purposes of this numberification all service or employment companynected with the companyduct of the above industry shall be deemed to be part of the industry when engaged in or by an employer engaged in that industry.

facts.text: Factories and offices attached to them situated at Lakshmiwadi and Sakharwadi, separated by hundreds of miles from head office at Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: In fact the factories and the offices attached to them are situated at Lakshmiwadi and Sakharwadi respectively and are separated by hundreds of miles from the head office at Bombay.

facts.text: Machinery purchased for industry landed at Bombay, received by head office, sent to factories.

anchor.surface_text: that at the head office there is accounts department, the establishment section, stores purchase section and legal department, and he pointed out that the machinery which is purchased for the industry is landed at Bombay, received by the head office and is then sent to the factories.

facts.text: Registrar appointed under s.11 of Act consistently refused to recognise staff of head office as coming under the notification.

anchor.surface_text: Incidentally we would like to add that the registrar appointed under s. 11 of the Act has companysistently refused to recognise the staff of the head office as companying under the numberification,

facts.text: Consistent practice against plea raised by respondent.

anchor.surface_text: and it is companymon ground that the companysistent practice in the matter so far is against the plea raised by the respondent.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds notification does not apply to head office of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: We must accordingly hold that the Labour Appellate Tribunal erred in law in holding that the case of the respondent was governed by the numberification.

facts.text: Appeal allowed, order of Labour Appellate Tribunal set aside, respondent's application dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the Labour Appellate Tribunal is set aside and the respondents application is dismissed.

facts.text: Act passed by Bombay Legislature to regulate relations of employers and employees, settlement of industrial disputes.

anchor.surface_text: The Act has been passed by the Bombay Legislature in order to regulate relations of employers and employees, to make provision for settlement of industrial disputes and to provide for certain other purposes.

facts.text: Notification issued in supersession of earlier notification.

anchor.surface_text: It has been issued by the Government of Bombay in exercise of the powers companyferred on it by s. 2, sub-section  4 , of the Act, and in supersession of an earlier numberification,

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal read notification as referring to sugar industry as such.

anchor.surface_text: Unfortunately the Labour Appellate Tribunal has read the numberification as though it referred to the sugar industry as such. That is a serious infirmity in the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Head office has accounts department, establishment section, stores purchase section, legal department.

holdings.text: The notification No. 1131-46 does not apply to the head office of the appellant at Bombay and the case of the respondent stenographer employed there is not governed by it.

anchor.surface_text: We must accordingly hold that the Labour Appellate Tribunal erred in law in holding that the case of the respondent was governed by the numberification.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deliberate narrow phrasing 'manufacture of sugar and its by-products' rather than 'sugar industry'; specific inclusions avoid surplusage under s.2(19); deeming note requires services to be 'engaged in that industry', not satisfied by head office functions.

holdings.text: The notification deliberately uses the phrase 'the manufacture of sugar and its by-products' and not 'sugar industry as such', requiring a limited rather than broad construction.

anchor.surface_text: It is significant that the numberification applies number to sugar industry as such but to the manufacture of sugar and its by-products. If the expression sugar industry had been used it would have been possible to companystrue that expression in a broader sense

holdings.reasoning_summary: Broad 'sugar industry' would incorporate s.2(19) definition allowing wider scope, but different phraseology chosen intentionally; Labour Appellate Tribunal erred by treating as sugar industry.

holdings.text: The specific inclusion of clauses (1) and (2) in the notification indicates that 'manufacture of sugar and its by-products' has a limited scope, as broader reading would render them superfluous given s.2(19)(b)(i).

anchor.surface_text: Besides, the inclusion of the two items specified in cls.  1  and  2  is also significant. Section 2 19  b  i  shows that industry includes agriculture and agricultural operations. Now, if the manufacture of sugar and its by-products had the same meaning as the expression sugar industry,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.2(19)(b)(i) already includes agriculture; explicit addition shows first part does not cover them, confirming narrow interpretation of core phrase.

holdings.text: The deeming note does not extend the notification's scope to the head office staff, as services must be 'engaged in that industry' despite connection to its conduct.

anchor.surface_text: Even so, though by the first part of the numbere some kinds of service or employment are deemed to be part of the industry in question by virtue of the fact that they are companynected with the companyduct of the said industry, the latter part of the numbere requires

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deeming limited by requirement of engagement 'in that industry'; head office stenographer's role (accounts, purchase, etc.) and machinery handling do not qualify as factories/offices are distant.

holdings.text: Prevailing administrative practice (registrar's refusal to recognize head office staff) is irrelevant to statutory construction of the notification, though consistent with it.

anchor.surface_text: Incidentally we would like to add that the registrar appointed under s. 11 of the Act has companysistently refused to recognise the staff of the head office as companying under the numberification,... It is perfectly true that in companystruing the numberification the prevailing practice can have numberrelevance

holdings.reasoning_summary: Construction based on text, not practice; mentioned incidentally as confirmatory only.

holdings.text: Similar notifications and decisions under s.2(3) for textile industry are not relevant or useful for construing this notification under s.2(4).

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in the companyrts below reference was made to a similar numberification issued in respect of textile industry under s. 2, sub-section  3 , of the Act and the relevant decisions companystruing the said numberification were cited. We do number think any useful purpose

holdings.reasoning_summary: Different provision and context; no purpose served by consideration.
